comment.author: 18885703@N00
comment._content: 'Nah-pooh' is in the lyrics to that song 'Good-byee', isn't it? "Bonsoir old thing, cheerio, chin-chin; nah-poo, toodle-oo, good-byee..."

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/belvedere] You are dead right, thank you! I couldn't understand what Nah-Pooh was about at all - so pleased...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: According to this website, "No.11 General Hospital" was at Genoa in Italy - www.anzacday.org.au/digging/hospitals.html

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
From a nurse's account of life there - www.scarletfinders.co.uk/153.html
There was one General and two Stationary Hospitals at Genoa. The first in a large hotel, the others in schools. Two of them already had patients and the other was being put in order. As there was no heating in the hotel, the building was intensely cold; it was, however, a very fine hotel with a marble staircase and beautiful baths, though at the time the baths were of little use, as there was no hot water. In the schools were some stoves which the patients thoroughly enjoyed. Later on we had an Infectious Hospital at Genoa, also a very nice hostel for sisters coming from the United Kingdom or moving about the country.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
It seems from the chit-chat on this site ( 1914-1918.invisionzone.com/forums/index.php?showtopic=166514 ) that the hospital was at the Hotel Miramare - it.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Hotel_Miramare_di_Genova -
With the outbreak of World War I, towards the end of 1916, the imposing building was converted into a hospital and housed over 500 wounded and subsequently transformed into barracks at the disposal of the troops of the 332 Infantry º American who held the headquarters until March 1919 . A year later he returned the hotel to its former glory.

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: The correct motto of the Royal Army Medical Corps would be "IN ARDUIS FIDELIS" (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Army_Medical_Corps). I could not find a meaning of "ARDUS" and I wonder if this error had been made ​​intentionally or accidentally.

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: K.R.R: King's Royal Rifle Corps (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/King%27s_Royal_Rifle_Corps) D.O.R.A.: Defence of the Realm Act (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Defence_of_the_Realm_Act_1914) G.R.O.: General Register Office (?) (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_Register_Office)

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: More about "NAH-POOH!", evidently a corruption of the French 'il n'y a plus', meaning ‘there’s none left’, or more generally, ‘no good’ - languagehat.com/narpoo/
